linkTarget.anchoringText: Dynamic simulation models were built to model reservoir behavior using the Chevron Extended Application Reservoir Simulator (CHEARS™). Given the high implication of breakthrough times to recovery in these wells, local grid refinements were further used near the wells. These enabled clearer understanding of the water and gas flow behavior and breakthrough around the wells the reservoir simulations. Figure 7 and Figure 8 shows a snapshot of cross-sections of the O-03 and M-01 simulation models at end of history with the LGRs in the planned area for the wells.

image-wrap.label: Figure 7
image-wrap.caption: M-01 Reservoir Model Cross-section at the end of history showing M-01_Well-1

formatted-caption.caption-text: M-01 Reservoir Model Cross-section at the end of history showing M-01_Well-1

linkTarget.anchoringText: Dynamic simulation models were built to model reservoir behavior using the Chevron Extended Application Reservoir Simulator (CHEARS™). Given the high implication of breakthrough times to recovery in these wells, local grid refinements were further used near the wells. These enabled clearer understanding of the water and gas flow behavior and breakthrough around the wells the reservoir simulations. Figure 7 and Figure 8 shows a snapshot of cross-sections of the O-03 and M-01 simulation models at end of history with the LGRs in the planned area for the wells.

image-wrap.label: Figure 8
image-wrap.caption: Model Cross-section in the O-03 reservoir at the end of history showing O-03_Well-1

formatted-caption.caption-text: Model Cross-section in the O-03 reservoir at the end of history showing O-03_Well-1

linkTarget.anchoringText: Depth prognosis were optimized using offset well depths, stratigraphic thicknesses of the most recent well data and sensitivities from the simulation model. After landing the wells at the pre-determined depth in the reservoir, pressure points were taken to confirm at various points in the reservoirs and plotted against depth to confirm the gas-oil contact. The pressures provided a second validation of the contacts, particularly considering the non-classic log signatures encountered in some of the wells. Figure 9 shows an example from one of the M-01 reservoir wells, with oil showing gas-like log signature.

image-wrap.label: Figure 9
image-wrap.caption: M-01 New Drill Reservoir Log Section showing Non-Classic Signature for Oil

formatted-caption.caption-text: M-01 New Drill Reservoir Log Section showing Non-Classic Signature for Oil
